pageData.text: In this investigation students will observe the color of light emitted from excited metal ions. This information will be used to partially determine the identity of an unknown salt. Each salt provided has a unique color to help with metal determination. Students will observe household light sources and determine the spectrum of the light emitted. The unknown metal spectrum will be identified by comparing it with the known metal spectrums.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Household Light Sources - 10 minutes
Activity 2: Spectroscope Calibration - 15 minutes
Activity 3: Metal Light Emission - 50 minutes
Activity 4: Calculation of Hydrogen Quantum Numbers - 20 minutes
Cleanup - 5 minutes

pageData.text: When researchers at Harvard College Observatory were assigned to survey and classify all the visible stars in the night sky, they realized this classification system would need to be based on spectroscopic analysis to demonstrate the immense variety found in stars. Edward Pickering led a group of astronomers, who happened to all be females and thus given the nickname “Pickering’s Harem,” who created the Draper System. Annie Jump Cannon organized seven subcategories: O, B, A, F, G, K, and M with further delineation with a 0-9 designation.<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup> These categories were based on star color, from blue to red. Dr. Cecilia Payne further correlated a star’s absorption features seen via spectrometric analysis and the temperature of the star.<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup> The Hertzsprung-Russel diagram incorporates the relationships between the temperature of a star, or color, versus the luminosity (which was discovered to be related to the star’s mass). Our sun is classified as a G2V star which is also known as a yellow dwarf.<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>

1Lee, C. (2013, March 4). Women of astronomy. Northern Virginia Astronomy Club.
https://www.novac.com/wp/blog/women-of-astronomy/
2Zirin, H. (n.d.). Sun. Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/place/Sun

pageData.desc: A stylized illustration of the sun as a celestial body.
pageData.altText: A stylized illustration of the sun as a celestial body.

pageData.text: Many holidays are celebrated with fireworks that illuminate the sky with a variety of colored lights. The metal ions in fireworks are chosen specifically to create the assortment of observed colors. This colored light is produced by excitation and subsequent relaxation of the electrons in the metals.

Light emission by atoms is a foundational principle of quantum chemistry. Atoms contain electrons that occupy discrete energy levels. The actual energy of each state (level) depends upon several factors: the nuclear charge, the distance of the electron from the nucleus, and the number of other electrons between the nucleus and the electron of interest.

Bohr’s Model of the Hydrogen AtomNiels Bohr made one of the first large breakthroughs in atom modeling and light quantization using the spectrum of hydrogen. Bohr developed a theory that electrons could only occupy certain distinct energy levels around the hydrogen nucleus. An example of these quantized energy states are shown in Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1. Diagram of hydrogen energy state transitions with emitted light color.
pageData.altText: Figure 1. Diagram of hydrogen energy state transitions with emitted light color.

pageData.text: To transition an electron from one level to another, a discrete amount of energy must be emitted or absorbed. Hydrogen is the easiest to observe because it only contains one electron. For light emitted by hydrogen, the energy can be determined as follows.ΔE = ℎc λ

Where λ is the wavelength of the light in meters, c is the speed of light (3.00 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>8</sup> meters per second), h is Planck’s constant (6.63 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>-34</sup> joules seconds), and ΔE is the change in energy in joules.

This energy can be used to identify the <button class='glossary-text'>quantum number</button> of the energy level the electron occupied. Quantum numbers identify the discrete energy levels of electrons. Quantum numbers are always integers. In hydrogen they start at 1, which is considered the <button class='glossary-text'>ground state</button>. If an electron is in an orbital with a quantum number higher than 1, it is considered to be in the <button class='glossary-text'>excited state</button>. There is more than one excited state and electrons can relax between individual excited states. In fact, with hydrogen visible light is only emitted when the electron relaxes to an orbital with a quantum number of 2. For visible light, the electron’s quantum number prior to relaxing to the n = 2 state can be calculated as follows.
ΔE = (2.18 × 10−18J) ( 1 nf2 - 1 ni2 )

Where ΔE is the change in energy calculated earlier, nf is the quantum number of the final orbital, and ni is the quantum number of the initial orbital. Since hydrogen’s visible spectral lines all have an nf = 2, the initial quantum number is easily calculated. These calculations will be performed in Activity 4. Bohr’s calculations for quantum numbers only work for hydrogen. For other elements electron configurations become increasingly complicated and Bohr’s equations are insufficient. Excited electrons still emit photons and the energy’s magnitude depends on the energy of the levels being transitioned between. The number and type of transitions depend both on the energy level structure of a given chemical species and on various quantum selection rules. These properties are unique to each element and give rise to characteristic element emission energies. Since each electron can undergo many transitions and most elements have many electrons, emission spectra can consist of a very large number of discrete wavelengths.

These wavelength profiles can be leveraged for scientific pursuits and practical effects. For example, sodium emits light at 589.3 nm. Areas surrounding astronomical observatories use low pressure sodium street lights to minimize light pollution. The observatories can filter out light at specific wavelengths and still produce credible, reproducible results even in dense urban areas. At your next opportunity, look at some nearby street lights at night. If they emit a strong yellow light, there is a good chance they are sodium lights.

The majority of light we observe is from continuous emission spectra. This light contains so many emitted radiation frequencies that the lines overlap. The light appears white, but it is really a rainbow of colors. Common continuous emission sources are incandescent light bulbs, heated metals in general, and flames containing soot such as a butane lighter. Notice that all these sources are solids, e.g., the wire filament in a light bulb and soot particles in a candle flame. The atoms and molecules in heated solids are continuously bumping against each other because they are so close. This dynamic contact causes the excitation energy to transform into kinetic energy, which is not quantized. As a solid’s temperature is raised, more of the radiation is emitted at shorter wavelengths. One example of this phenomenon is an electric stove. When the stove is first turned on, the coils warm and emit infrared radiation, which is emission at wavelengths greater than 700 nm. As the coils continue to heat up, red light is emitted. Most stoves do not heat above the red hot stage, but if it continued the coil would appear orange, then yellow, and eventually white as the temperature increased.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the reason why, for elements other than hydrogen, Bohr’s equations are insufficient?

options.text: The energy’s magnitude depends on the energy of the levels being transitioned between.
The other elements do not have electron shells.
The other elements do not emit photons.
Air gets in the way of being able to see electrons.
The energy's magnitude depends on the element’s number of valence electrons.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Excited electrons still emit photons, but the energy’s magnitude depends on the energy of the levels being transitioned between.

hintData.body: Niels Bohr made one of the first large breakthroughs in atom modeling and light quantization using the spectrum of hydrogen. Bohr developed a theory that electrons could only occupy certain distinct energy levels around the hydrogen nucleus, which is illustrated in Figure 1. Bohr’s calculations for quantum numbers only work for hydrogen. With hydrogen, visible light is only emitted when the electron relaxes to an orbital with a quantum number of 2. For other elements, electron configurations become increasingly complicated, and Bohr’s equations are insufficient.

pageData.text: Using a spectroscopeA is an instrument that measures the wavelengths of light emitted from a light source. The spectroscope provided in this kit has three main components. There is a slit at one end of the spectroscope that allows light to enter the instrument. The light then travels to the diffraction grating where the light is reflected and refracted towards the scale at the far end of the spectroscope. The diffraction grating acts like hundreds of prisms, bending the light such that the colors are split and focused on the scale in discrete wavelengths. The numbers on the scale are roughly equivalent to the associated light wavelength, e.g., a 4 on the scale is equivalent to a 400 nm light wavelength.

pageData.desc: Figure 2. Diagram of how light enters a spectroscope and is diffracted into a spectrum.
pageData.altText: Figure 2. Diagram of how light enters a spectroscope and is diffracted into a spectrum.

pageData.text: To use the spectroscope, look through the diffraction grating and align the slit at the far end of the spectroscope with the light source being observed. Once the light source is properly aligned, the light spectrum will appear on the scale in the spectroscope. This light may be very faint and difficult to observe even under ideal circumstances.

In Activity 2, you will use a fluorescent light spectrum to calibrate your <button class='glossary-text'>spectroscope</button>. Modern fluorescent bulbs use a combination of elements to produce visible light. The most common elements are listed in Table 2.

The calibration in Activity 2 is then used to directly correlate the scale position observed in the spectroscope with a particular light wavelength. Activity 3 will use the spectroscope and the calibration curve constructed in Activity 2 to determine the prominent spectral lines and approximate wavelengths for four metal ions and an unknown metal ion mixture that you will identify.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the role of diffraction grating in a spectroscope?

options.text: It bends light, causing the colors to split into discrete wavelengths.
It magnifies the light so the individual colors can be observed.
It provides a ruler against which to measure the wavelength of each color.
It allows light to enter the spectroscope.
It emits light that can then be observed by the spectroscope.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The diffraction grating acts like hundreds of prisms, bending the light such that the colors are split and focused on the scale in discrete wavelengths.

pageData.question: An orange band is observed on the scale of your spectroscope near the number “6”. Which of the following best describes how to interpret this observation?

options.text: The wave of light is approximately 600 nm in length.
The wave of light is approximately 6 m in length.
The wave of light has approximately 600 J of energy.
The wave of light has approximately 6 kJ of energy.
There are approximately 6 waves of orange light in the light source.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The numbers on the scale are roughly equivalent to the associated light wavelength, so the orange wavelength is approximately 600 nm.

The numbers on the scale are roughly equivalent to the associated light wavelength, e.g., a 4 on the scale is equivalent to a 400 nm light wavelength. pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will view a household light source with the spectroscope and observe the spectrum. You will repeat this with two additional light sources. In Activity 2, you will graph the light wavelength versus scale position for a fluorescent light bulb, based on data collected in Activity 1. Then, you will create a trendline for the graph and determine the trendline equation. In Activity 3, you will dim the lights in your work area and light the Sterno® heater. Then, you will soak one of your flame sticks in water before holding it over the heater and observing the resulting flame. Next, you will observe the flame through the spectroscope. You will repeat this process for all five flame sticks. Finally, you will calculate the light wavelengths for each compound found on the flame sticks. In Activity 4, you will calculate the hydrogen quantum numbers for a given data set.

Then, you will create a trendline for the graph and determine the trendline equation. In Activity 3, you will dim the lights in your work area and light the Sterno® heater. Then, you will soak one of your flame sticks in water before holding it over the heater and observing the resulting flame. Next, you will observe the flame through the spectroscope. You will repeat this process for all five flame sticks. Finally, you will calculate the light wavelengths for each compound found on the flame sticks. In Activity 4, you will calculate the hydrogen quantum numbers for a given data set.

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement investigation kit for Atomic Emission and Flame Test, item number 580350, can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.
Wear your safety goggles and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation.

Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> contains flammable alcohol gel. Long hair should be tied back and loose clothing kept away from an open flame. The can will stay hot even after the flame is extinguished. Use Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> on a heat-resistant surface like a stovetop or trivet.

The potassium, lithium, sodium, and copper metal salts used are toxic when ingested. Handle with gloves at all time. Keep flame test sticks away from food storage locations, children, and pets to avoid accidental ingestion.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Kenny is viewing a red sparkler through a spectroscope. The wavelength he would expect to see on the spectroscope falls in which range?
Which of the following is the best description of how a spectroscope works?

options.text: Light enters the spectroscope and is refracted by diffraction grating onto a scale.
Light is filtered by the diffraction grating as it enters the spectroscope.
The spectroscope measures the amount of energy in a light source.
The spectroscope generates light patterns based on wavelength tables.
The spectroscope ionizes elements and projects the light onto a scale.

assestmentData.question: What is the purpose of viewing a fluorescent light with the spectroscope in Activity 2 of this investigation?

options.text: to calibrate the spectroscope
to create a reflection apparatus
to determine the wavelength of white light
to identify the colors of a rainbow
to compare its spectrum to that of an LED light

options.text: excited
normal
ground
primary

assestmentData.question: Shown here are 5 spectra representing 5 light sources. Which light source would you choose if short wavelength light is desired?

imageData.desc: Five different spectra from a spectroscope representing five different light sources. Light source one has a spectrum with five lines equally spaced across the spectrum. Light source two has one band near the middle of the spectrum. Light source three has three bands, two located at either end of the spectrum and one located near the middle. Light source four has four bands located on the left half of the spectrum. Light source five has three bands located on the right half of the spectrum.
imageData.altText: Five different spectra from a spectroscope representing five different light sources. Light source one has a spectrum with five lines equally spaced across the spectrum. Light source two has one band near the middle of the spectrum. Light source three has three bands, two located at either end of the spectrum and one located near the middle. Light source four has four bands located on the left half of the spectrum. Light source five has three bands located on the right half of the spectrum.

pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Obtain all materials.
Select a work area with a heat-resistant surface, preferably a stovetop or trivet.
Remove any flammable household materials from the work area.
In Activity 1, you will observe and record the spectra for household light sources, including a fluorescent light bulb.
Using the <button class='glossary-text'>spectroscope</button>, view a fluorescent light bulb.
Record the color and scale position of the three strongest spectrum lines in Data Table 1. Start on the left and proceed to the right.
Observe two additional light sources and record whether the light has a continuous or line spectrum in Data Table 1.
If the light has a line spectrum record the color and scale position of the spectrum lines in Data Table 1.
Different types of lights will likely have different spectra. Feel free to be creative and look at different types of light sources in the world around you.
In Activity 2, you will calibrate your <button class='glossary-text'>spectroscope</button> by graphing the fluorescent light data from Activity 1.
Copy the scale position and color for each observed line from the fluorescent light bulb into Data Table 2. The number of lines may vary based on the particular light source.
Reference to write the line’s wavelength in Data Table 2.
Use a graphing program to create a scatterplot graph with the light wavelength on the y-axis and the scale position on the x-axis.
On the graph, create a best-fit line (linear trendline) for your scatter plots.
Set the y-intercept of the best-fit line to 0.
Display the trendline equation on your graph and record it in the Lab Notebook.
In Activity 3, you will observe metal light emission by heating flame test sticks and observing the flame color through the <button class='glossary-text'>spectroscope</button>.
This activity works best in a darkened space. If possible, have an assistant to hold the coated sticks in the flame, so that observing the color of the flame is easier.
Fill a plastic cup with tap water.
Take the flame test stick coated in potassium chloride (KCl) and break it into four pieces. Refer to the materials section for help identifying the test sticks by color.
Place the flame test stick pieces in the water in the plastic cup and allow them to soak for 10-15 minutes. This prevents the wood burning and influencing the color of the flame.
Open the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can by gently prying up the lid with a key or knife.

Light the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> heater with a match or lighter. A Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> flame is nearly invisible in a bright room and appears pale blue when the lights are darkened.
Turn off any interior lights and make the working area as dark as you can while still feeling comfortable performing the task.

The Sterno® heater will get extremely hot as the activity progresses. It is important to select a suitable heat-resistant working area so you do not need to move the can. Keep the lid and oven mitts or tongs handy. The Sterno® lid can be slid over the flame to immediately extinguish the can. Sterno® can be relit if extinguished.

With the forceps, remove one of the soaked flame test stick pieces and carefully hold it over the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> heater. The wood will burn quickly then reveal the unique colored flame of the metal ion.
Record the color and intensity of the stick’s flame in Data Table 3.
If necessary, add additional pieces of flame test stick to the can for prolonged or brighter color.
View the flame through your and record any spectrum line(s) observed in Data Table 3.
Repeat this activity with the remaining salts in order (LiCl, NaCl, CuCl<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>, and the unknown salt).

Calculate the light wavelength for each line observed in all the compounds. Use the best fit line equation determined in Activity 2 to perform this calculation. Replace x with the observed scale position and solve for y.
In Activity 4, you will calculate hydrogen <button class='glossary-text'>quantum numbers</button> for wavelengths in a given data set.
In Data Table 4, four wavelengths of light were observed in the hydrogen light spectrum.
Convert the wavelengths from nanometers to meters and record the values in Data Table 4.
Calculate ΔE for each wavelength and record the values in Data Table 4.
Calculate the initial , ni, for each spectral line and record the values in Data Table 4.

text: With an oven mitt or tongs, slide the lid over the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> flame to extinguish.
Once cool, the Sterno<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> can and remaining flame test sticks can be disposed in a waste receptacle.
Sanitize the workspace.

Say a fireworks engineer was planning a Christmas show and wanted to create a red explosion followed by a green one. Based on the flames observed, which metal salts should they use?
